hints_html:
How does the dimension of the nullspace relate to the number of pivot columns of the matrix?

Recall we can find the nullspace by row-reducing.
hints_latex:
How does the dimension of the nullspace relate to the number of pivot
columns of the matrix?
Recall we can find the nullspace by row-reducing.
hints_raw:
How does the dimension of the nullspace relate to the number of pivot columns of the matrix?
Recall we can find the nullspace by row-reducing.
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
In part (a) we found that

\[\begin{aligned} A=\begin{bmatrix} 12&4&1&0 \\ 0& 0&1&0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

The matrix A has 2 pivot columns and so by rank-nullity theorem

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}\dim(N(A))=4-\dim(R(A))=4-2=2\end{aligned}\]

and so there are two basis vectors for the nullspace. To find them we could row reduce A or notice that, at x = 0,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}3a_{1}(0)^2+2a_2(0)+a_3=0\end{aligned}\]

gives \(a_3=0\). Using the value at x=2

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}12a_1+4a_2+a_3=12a_1+4a_2=0,\end{aligned}\]

gives \(a_2=-3a_1\). Since neither equation depends on \(a_4\) then it is a free variable. Hence, the basis of N(A) is

\(\vec{a}=\begin{bmatrix} a_1\\ a_2\\ a_3\\ a_4 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} a_1\\ -3a_1\\ 0\\ a_4 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -3\\ 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}a_1+\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}a_4\)

Hence, \(\vec{a_1}=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -3\\ 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix},\vec{a_2}=\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\)
sols_raw:
In [[Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH307/December 2012/Question 01 (a)|part (a)]] we found that

:<math>A=\begin{bmatrix}
12&4&1&0 \\ 
0& 0&1&0
\end{bmatrix}</math>

The matrix ''A'' has 2 pivot columns and so by rank-nullity theorem

:<math>
\displaystyle{}\dim(N(A))=4-\dim(R(A))=4-2=2
</math>

and so there are two basis vectors for the nullspace.  To find them we could row reduce ''A'' or notice that, at ''x = 0'',

:<math>
\displaystyle{}3a_{1}(0)^2+2a_2(0)+a_3=0
</math>

gives <math>a_3=0</math>.  Using the value at ''x=2''

:<math>
\displaystyle{}12a_1+4a_2+a_3=12a_1+4a_2=0,
</math>

gives <math>a_2=-3a_1</math>.  Since neither equation depends on <math>a_4</math> then it is a free variable.  Hence, the basis of ''N(A)'' is

<math>\vec{a}=\begin{bmatrix}
a_1\\ 
a_2\\ 
a_3\\ 
a_4
\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}
a_1\\ 
-3a_1\\ 
0\\ 
a_4
\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}
1\\ 
-3\\ 
0\\ 
0
\end{bmatrix}a_1+\begin{bmatrix}
0\\ 
0\\ 
0\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}a_4</math>

Hence, <math>\vec{a_1}=\begin{bmatrix}
1\\ 
-3\\ 
0\\ 
0
\end{bmatrix},\vec{a_2}=\begin{bmatrix}
0\\ 
0\\ 
0\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}</math>
statement_html:
In this question we will work with polynomials of degree 3 written

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle p(x) = a_1x^3 + a_2x^2 + a_3x + a_4\end{aligned}\]

(b) Show that dim(N(A)) = 2 and bind a basis a1, a2 for N(A).
statement_latex:
In this question we will work with polynomials of degree 3 written

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
p(x) = a_1x^3 + a_2x^2 + a_3x + a_4
\end{align*}

\textbf{(b)} Show that \emph{dim(N(A)) = 2} and bind a basis
\textbf{a}\textsubscript{1}, \textbf{a}\textsubscript{2} for
\emph{N(A)}.
statement_raw:
In this question we will work with polynomials of degree 3 written

:<math> \displaystyle
p(x) = a_1x^3 + a_2x^2 + a_3x + a_4
</math>

'''(b)''' Show that ''dim(N(A)) = 2'' and bind a basis '''a'''<sub>1</sub>, '''a'''<sub>2</sub> for ''N(A)''.
